title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging tribes' authority to provide programs and services, develop economies, and govern their lands as sovereign entities. Indian tribes have the authority to tax, operate like other governments, finance projects with bonds, and maintain tax exemptions. Tax parity for tribal governments aligns with Federal treaties recognizing their sovereignty. Tribes face challenges accessing capital for infrastructure and job creation. Indian tribes face challenges in developing strong governance and economies due to statutory restrictions and exclusion from key provisions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Congress has the authority to regulate commerce with Indian tribes to further tribal self-governance. The United States government affirms its government-to-government relationship with Indian tribes. Indian tribes are treated as states with respect to bond issuance. Indian tribal governments are treated as states for certain purposes, including special rules for tax-exempt bonds issued by them. The Secretary of the Treasury establishes a national bond volume cap based on the State population formula approach. The Department of the Interior, in consultation with the Census Bureau, provides annual estimates for the national bond volume cap. Indian tribal governments can seek an allocation of this cap under regulations set by the Secretary. Section 7871 of the Code is amended to repeal certain requirements. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of this Act, while the repeals made by subsection (b) apply to transactions and obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Treatment of pension and employee benefit plans by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and modifying the definition of governmental plan. The definition of a governmental plan under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is expanded to include plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans, allowing them to be treated as eligible employers under certain subsections. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 also apply to ensure compliance with the new provisions. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans, allowing them to be treated as eligible employers under certain subsections. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans, allowing them to be treated as eligible employers under certain subsections. Amendments include adding "tribal" after "State" in the domestic relations order section and making conforming amendments to the Act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans, allowing them to be treated as eligible employers under certain subsections. Amendments include adding "tribal" after "State" in the domestic relations order section and making conforming amendments to the Act. A new paragraph is added to specify entities eligible for employee benefit plans established by Indian tribal governments or related entities. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include Indian tribal governments in the definition of governmental plans. Amendments made to section 1321(b)(2) involve removing certain language and inserting a comma. The effective date for these amendments applies to years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. Tribal foundations and charities treated like charities funded and controlled by other governmental funders and sponsors. The amendment expands the definition of "governmental unit" to include Indian tribal governments and related entities. Additionally, certain supporting organizations are subject to specific regulations under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment expands the definition of "governmental unit" to include Indian tribal governments and related entities. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. IMPROVING TRIBAL CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES' ACCESS TO FEDERAL PARENT LOCATOR SERVICE AND TAX REFUND OFFSETS. Amendment to the Social Security Act allows tribal child support enforcement agencies access to Federal Parent Locator Service and tax refund offsets. Amendment to the Social Security Act allows Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for a grant under section 455(f) to be subject to the same provisions as states with approved plans. Additionally, the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions related to tax refund offsets. The amendment to the Social Security Act extends provisions to Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants under section 455(f), aligning them with states. Additionally, the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to incorporate tax refund offset provisions. For this subsection, a reference to a State includes Indian tribes or tribal organizations described in section 464(d) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 7 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include Indian tribal governments in determining special needs for the adoption credit. Effective for taxable years after enactment.
